question: Question_06
statement:
Stalagmites are cone-shaped mineral deposits which rise from the floors
of limestone caves. They form over millenia as dripping water deposits
calcium carbonate onto the cave floor.

Consider a cone-shaped stalagmite with a length always equal to five
times its radius. Suppose the stalagmite's height increases at a rate of
0.13 millimetres per year. Write down two expressions for the rate of
change of its volume: \emph{(i)} with respect to its height \emph{h},
and \emph{(ii)} with respect to its radius \emph{r}.

Hint: the volume \emph{V} of a cone with radius \emph{r} and height
\emph{h} is equal to $\frac13 \pi r^2h$.
hints:
What fact about the proportions of the stalagmite can you use to relate
the variables \emph{r} and \emph{h}? Once you have done this, you can
write the volume formula either in terms of \emph{h} (for part i) or
\emph{r} (for part ii).

Try differentiating the equation relating \emph{h} and \emph{r}. What
does this tell you about the relationship between $dh/dt$ and $dr/dt$?
